topic.title: Why are you voting for Jill Stein?
topic.body: Everybody I know is voting for Jill Stein. Why do you love Jill Stein? Is it her stance on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, or is it her life-long determination to end healthcare discrimination? Or one of her other powerful stances?

6_1KzaKud9cUZB7HcgHnhrZqyuq2NnTeW6PR.body:
> [jarmund](#comment_4_1CiHRyU3rHFGR1rEyTPDYH7xjN99iPZkBJ): Why? I'm not a Tor users but I don't know why is it a problem to have many Tor users on Zeronet?

Tor is slow, and requires the resources of volunteers. When connecting directly to Zeronet you are contributing the most possible, personally. It is also more efficient.

1_1JecQYorYpL9F9vArLj13LKvc3v3iSdDHA.body: Zeronet is mostly about preventing censorship. Zeronet is NOT anonymity-oriented - yet. This of this as a public forum. Just like clearnet, except without any central point of failure. Your own personal "get unfiltered info" system (but the spooks will be here, guaranteed).

5_1C6qdRAX8iYqSB7TfUxk91yW8Y2SBKNgfA.body:
Cool site! Zeronet isn't for anonymity. Zeronet is for maintaining connections even if DNS is lost. In addition, it could prove the most useful blogging platform, since each user becomes a server, making any slightly popular site impossible to take down.

Privacy apps will have to be built atop Zeronet, and it can be done. 

I just looked at the script. It's very simple. It calls http://l2.io/ip.js?var=myip, which is just an external site that responds with your IP address. So all it's doing is accessing an external site.

But fixing that problem isn't enough, because malicious javascript could cause deanonymization anyway. It's a somewhat routine event. Every few years there's a zero day discovered where javascript deanonymizes users. So I guess you could turn off scripts and try to get your browser to not load content that's not through the zeronet local proxy. But I wouldn't trust the browser to do either reliably.
